title: Benefits of Shavasana (Corpse Pose)
content: Shavasana, or Corpse Pose, is often considered one of the most important yoga postures. It is typically performed at the end of a yoga session to facilitate deep relaxation and integrate the benefits of the practice. Benefits include reducing stress, lowering blood pressure, relieving fatigue, and calming the mind. It helps in rejuvenating the body and mind by allowing the nervous system to switch to a parasympathetic state.

title: Contraindications for Headstand (Sirsasana)
content: Headstand (Sirsasana) is an advanced inversion that requires significant strength and balance. It is contraindicated for individuals with high blood pressure, heart conditions, neck injuries, or glaucoma (due to increased pressure in the eyes). Pregnant women, especially those who are not experienced practitioners, should avoid this pose to prevent falls or undue strain. Menstruating women are also often advised to avoid inversions depending on their comfort and tradition.

title: Introduction to Pranayama: Nadi Shodhana
content: Nadi Shodhana, or Alternate Nostril Breathing, is a calming pranayama technique. It helps balance the left and right hemispheres of the brain and purifies the energy channels (nadis). To practice: sit comfortably, close the right nostril with the thumb, inhale through the left. Close left with ring finger, exhale right. Inhale right, close right, exhale left. This clears the mind and reduces anxiety.

title: Downward-Facing Dog (Adho Mukha Svanasana)
content: Downward-Facing Dog is a foundational pose that stretches the hamstrings, calves, and shoulders while strengthening the arms and legs. It energizes the body and improves digestion. Beginners should focus on keeping the spine straight, even if that means bending the knees slightly. Avoid collapsing into the shoulders; press firmly through the hands to lift the hips high.

title: Yoga for Pregnancy: Safety Guidelines
content: Prenatal yoga can be highly beneficial but requires modifications. Avoid lying on the belly (prone poses) after the first trimester. Avoid deep twists that compress the abdomen; open twists are safer. Inversions should be practiced with caution or avoided. Lying flat on the back (supine) for long periods can compress the vena cava, so side-lying is preferred for relaxation. Always consult a doctor before starting.

title: Warrior I (Virabhadrasana I)
content: Warrior I strengthens the legs, opens the hips and chest, and improves focus. Stand with feet wide apart, turn one foot out 90 degrees and the other in 45 degrees. Bend the front knee to 90 degrees, keeping the back leg straight. Raise arms overhead. Keep the hips squared to the front. Great for building stamina and stability.

title: Warrior II (Virabhadrasana II)
content: Warrior II builds leg strength and opens the hips. From a wide stance, turn the front foot out and bend the knee. Arms extend parallel to the floor, gazing over the front fingertips. Keep the torso vertical, not leaning forward. This pose increases endurance and concentration.

title: Tree Pose (Vrikshasana)
content: Tree Pose improves balance and stability. Stand on one leg, placing the sole of the other foot on the inner thigh or calf (avoid the knee joint). Hands can be in prayer position or overhead. Fix your gaze on a point for balance. It strengthens the legs and core while calming the mind.

title: Child's Pose (Balasana)
content: Child's Pose is a restful grounding pose. Kneel on the floor, toes together, knees apart. Sit back on heels and extend arms forward or alongside the body, resting the forehead on the mat. It gently stretches the hips, thighs, and ankles while relieving back pain and stress.

title: Cobra Pose (Bhujangasana)
content: Cobra Pose strengthens the spine and opens the chest. Lie on the stomach, hands under shoulders. Press into the floor to lift the chest, keeping elbows close to the body. Keep the pelvis grounded. It invigorates the heart and improves posture but should be avoided if you have a recent back injury or are pregnant.

title: Kapalbhati Pranayama (Skull Shining Breath)
content: Kapalbhati is an energizing breathing technique involving passive inhalations and forceful exhalations. It cleanses the respiratory system and strengthens abdominal muscles. Avoid if you have high blood pressure, heart disease, hernia, or are pregnant.

title: Benefits of Twist Poses
content: Twisting poses like Ardha Matsyendrasana stimulate digestion and improve spinal mobility. They are believed to 'wring out' toxins from the organs. However, twists should be approached with care if you have spinal disc issues. Deep closed twists are contraindicated during pregnancy.

title: Bridge Pose (Setu Bandhasana)
content: Bridge Pose strengthens the back, glutes, and hamstrings, and opens the chest. Lie on your back, knees bent, feet flat. Lift hips towards the ceiling, clasping hands under the back. Good for stimulating the thyroid and reducing anxiety. Avoid neck strain.

title: Plank Pose (Phalakasana)
content: Plank Pose is a core strengthener that also works the arms and shoulders. Keep the body in a straight line from head to heels. Engage the core to prevent the lower back from sagging. It prepares the body for more advanced arm balances.

title: Contraindications for Bikram/Hot Yoga
content: Hot yoga involves practicing in a heated room. It promotes flexibility but carries risks of dehydration and heat exhaustion. Individuals with low blood pressure, heart conditions, or history of heat stroke should be cautious. Pregnant women are generally advised to avoid hot yoga due to the risk of raising core body temperature too high.

title: Legs-Up-The-Wall (Viparita Karani)
content: A restorative inversion where legs are extended up a wall while lying on the back. It relieves tired legs, improves circulation, and calms the nervous system. Safe for most people, but those with glaucoma or serious neck issues should use caution or support.

title: Triangle Pose (Trikonasana)
content: Triangle Pose stretches the legs, hips, and spine. Stand wide, turn one foot out, reach forward and tilt to place the hand on the shin or floor, extending the other arm up. Improves balance and relieves backache. Avoid if you have low blood pressure or neck problems (look down instead of up).

title: Ujjayi Breath (Victorious Breath)
content: Ujjayi breath creates a soft sound in the throat by slightly constricting the glottis. It warms the body, focuses the mind, and regulates breath during asana practice. Often used in Vinyasa and Ashtanga yoga.

title: Crow Pose (Bakasana)
content: Crow Pose is an arm balance that strengthens wrists, arms, and core. From a squat, place hands on the floor, knees on upper arms, and lift feet. Requires focus and balance. Contraindicated for carpal tunnel syndrome or pregnancy.

title: Seated Forward Bend (Paschimottanasana)
content: Stretches the spine and hamstrings. Sit with legs extended, hinge at hips to reach for feet. Calms the mind and relieves stress. Forceing the stretch can injure the lower back; use a strap if needed.

title: Camel Pose (Ustrasana)
content: A deep backbend that stretches the entire front body. Kneel and lean back to hold heels. Opens the heart and throat. energized the body. Avoid if you have serious lower back or neck injuries.

title: Cat-Cow Stretch (Marjaryasana-Bitilasana)
content: A gentle flow between arching and rounding the back while on hands and knees. Warms up the spine and relieves tension. Safe for most, including during pregnancy (with care not to over-arch).

title: Eagle Pose (Garudasana)
content: A balancing pose where one leg wraps around the other and arms intertwine. Improves concentration and stretches shoulders and hips. Difficult for those with knee injuries.

title: Risks of Hyperextension
content: Hyperextension occurs when a joint moves beyond its normal range of motion. Common in elbows and knees during yoga. It can lead to injury and instability. Practitioners should keep a 'micro-bend' in joints to engage muscles and protect ligaments.

title: Bhramari Pranayama (Bee Breath)
content: Bhramari involves making a humming sound while exhaling. It instantly calms the mind and is excellent for reducing anger, anxiety, and insomnia. Safe for almost everyone.

title: Boat Pose (Navasana)
content: Boat Pose targets the abdominal muscles and hip flexors. Balance on sit bones, legs lifted, forming a V-shape. Builds core strength and determination. Avoid during pregnancy or menstruation.

title: Fish Pose (Matsyasana)
content: A counter-pose to shoulder stand. Lie back, arching the chest up while keeping the head on the floor. Stretches the neck and throat. Good for respiratory issues. Avoid if you have neck or lower back injuries.

title: Restorative Yoga Benefits
content: Restorative yoga uses props to support the body in poses held for long periods. It triggers the relaxation response, deep healing, and stress relief. Beneficial for anyone recovering from illness or injury.

title: Yin Yoga vs. Yang Yoga
content: Yang yoga (like Vinyasa) targets muscles and builds heat. Yin yoga targets deep connective tissues (fascia, ligaments) with passive poses held for minutes. Yin enhances flexibility and joint health but requires patience.

title: General Yoga Safety Tips
content: Listen to your body (Ahimsa/Non-harming). Don't push into pain. Stay hydrated. Wear comfortable clothing. Warm up before deep stretches. If you have a medical condition, consult a doctor and inform your instructor.
